skill.name: css-development:refactor
skill.description: This skill should be used when refactoring existing CSS from inline styles or utility classes to semantic patterns. Triggers on "refactor CSS", "extract styles", "consolidate CSS", "convert inline", "clean up styles", "migrate to semantic". Transforms to semantic classes with dark mode and tests.
skill.summary: This skill should be used when refactoring existing CSS from inline styles or utility classes to sem...
skill.author: 2389-research

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill with no executable code. Provides guidance for AI assistants to help refactor CSS. No network calls, file modifications, or external command execution capabilities are built into the skill itself.

content.value_statement: Convert inline styles and scattered utility classes into maintainable semantic CSS. Add dark mode support while preserving existing visual behavior. Creates organized component styles that are easier to maintain and update.
actual_capabilities: Extract inline styles from components to semantic CSS classes
Consolidate repeated utility class combinations into reusable @apply compositions
Add dark mode variants to all refactored styles
Identify and reuse existing component patterns before creating new classes
Add static CSS tests and component rendering tests for refactored code
limitations: Does not execute refactoring automatically - provides guidance for AI to follow
Cannot verify visual output in browser environments
Requires human review for edge cases and accessibility considerations

output_examples.input: Extract inline styles from my React Button component to semantic CSS
output: Analyzed Button component for inline styles and utility classes
Created .button-primary semantic class with hover states and transitions
Updated Button.tsx to use semantic classes
Added static CSS test for button-primary class

best_practices: Check existing component patterns before creating new semantic classes to avoid duplication
Always include both light and dark mode variants when creating new CSS classes
Add documentation comments explaining usage and what patterns each class replaces
anti_patterns: Creating new semantic classes without checking if similar patterns already exist
Adding dark mode only to backgrounds without updating text and border colors
Refactoring without adding tests to verify behavior is preserved

faq.question: Does this skill work with frameworks other than Tailwind?
faq.answer: Yes. The semantic patterns work with any CSS framework. You adapt the @apply composition for your framework.

faq.question: Will refactoring break my existing components?
faq.answer: The skill follows behavior-neutral refactoring. All classes are verified to preserve original visual output.

faq.question: Can I use this skill for CSS-in-JS solutions?
faq.answer: Yes. The extraction patterns apply to styled-components, emotion, and other CSS-in-JS libraries.

faq.question: How does dark mode detection work?
faq.answer: The skill checks for Tailwind dark: variants and adds missing ones to background, text, and border properties.

faq.question: Does this skill modify files directly?
faq.answer: No. The skill provides guidance for AI assistants. All file modifications require human approval and execution.

faq.question: How is this different from css-development:validate?
faq.answer: Refactor transforms existing code. Validate checks existing CSS against standards without making changes.
